001package imagingbook.lib.util;
002
003import java.io.File;
004import java.io.IOException;
005import java.io.InputStream;
006import java.net.URI;
007import java.net.URISyntaxException;
008import java.net.URL;
009import java.nio.file.FileSystem;
010import java.nio.file.FileSystemNotFoundException;
011import java.nio.file.FileSystems;
012import java.nio.file.Files;
013import java.nio.file.Path;
014import java.nio.file.Paths;
015import java.util.ArrayList;
016import java.util.Arrays;
017import java.util.Collections;
018import java.util.Iterator;
019import java.util.List;
020import java.util.stream.Stream;
021
022/**
023 * Any resource directory is supposed to contain a "marker" class 
024 * (any legal class name is OK) extending this class ({@link ResourceLocation}).
025 * This is to make sure that every resource location
026 * is also a Java package known to exist at compile time.
027 * For example, a marker class is defined in file {@code imagingbook.DATA.images.Resources.java} 
028 * as follows:
029 * <pre>
030 * package imagingbook.DATA.images;
031 * public class Resources extends ResourceLocation { }</pre>
032 * 
033 * All resources are assumed to be local in the SAME directory ONLY,
034 * thereby avoiding the use of strings to specify sub-directories.
035 * Here is an example how to access the associated resources from some other class:
036 * <pre>
037 * ResourceLocation rd = new imagingbook.DATA.images.Resources();
038 * Path path = rd.getResourcePath("boats.png");</pre>
039 * 
040 * Specifically, an image can be opened as follows:
041 * <pre>
042 * Path path = rd.getResourcePath("boats.png");
043 * ImagePlus im = IjUtils.openImage(path);
044 * ImageProcessor ip = im.getProcessor();
045 * ...</pre>
046 * 
047 * Note that under the canonical Maven project structure, the associated file 
048 * locations (package structure) are:
049 * <pre>
050 * src/main/java/imagingbook/DATA/images/Resources.java (the marker class extending {@link ResourceLocation})
051 * src/main/resources/imagingbook/DATA/images/boats.png ... (the actual resource files)</pre>
052 * 
053 * or (if resources are used for testing only)
054 * <pre>
055 * src/test/java/imagingbook/DATA/images/Resources.java (the marker class extending {@link ResourceLocation})
056 * src/test/resources/imagingbook/DATA/images/boats.png ... (the actual resource files)</pre>
057 * 
058 * <p>
059 * Note: To avoid marker classes showing up in the JavaDoc documentation,
060 * we use the following (internal) "convention":
061 * </p>
062 * <ul>
063 * <li>All root resource packages/directories are named {@code DATA} (deliberately
064 * upper-case to mark them as special packages, since Java package names are generally lower-case).</li>
065 * <li>The {@code pom.xml} file contains the following entry in the configuration
066 * of the {@code maven-javadoc-plugin}:<br>
067 * {@code <excludePackageNames>*.DATA.*</excludePackageNames>}
068 * </ul>
069 * Of course these packages could be named differently and excluded individually.
070 * 
071 * 
072 * @author WB
073 * @version 2020/11/22
074 */
075public abstract class ResourceLocation {
076        
077        private final Class<? extends ResourceLocation> clazz;
078        
079        protected ResourceLocation() {
080                this.clazz = this.getClass();
081        }
082
083        /**
084         * Determines if this class was loaded from
085         * a JAR file or from the file system.
086         * 
087         * @return true if contained in a JAR file, false otherwise
088         */
089        public boolean isInsideJAR() {
090                URL url = clazz.getProtectionDomain().getCodeSource().getLocation();
091                String path = url.getPath();
092                File file = new File(path);
093                return file.isFile();
094        }
095        
096//      /**
097//       * Returns the path to the file location of this class.
098//       * @return The path to this class.
099//       */
100//      public Path getResourcePath() {
101//              return getResourcePath("");
102//      }
103        
104        /**
105         * Returns the path to specified resource in this resource location.
106         *  
107         * @param resourceName The resource's simple name (including the file extension).
108         * If empty or {@code null}, the path to the resource container location (directory)
109         * is returned.
110         * @return The path to the specified resource or {@code null} if not found
111         */
112        public Path getResourcePath(String resourceName) {
113                URI uri = (resourceName == null) ? getURI("") : getURI(resourceName);
114                return (uri == null) ? null : uriToPath(uri);
115        }
116        
117        /**
118         * Returns the specified resource as an {@link InputStream}.
119         * This is essentially a wrapper to {@link Class#getResourceAsStream(String)}.
120         * 
121         * @param resourceName The resource's simple name (including file extension)
122         * @return A stream or {@code null} if the resource is not found.
123         */
124        public InputStream getResourceAsStream(String resourceName) {
125                return clazz.getResourceAsStream(resourceName);
126        }
127        
128        /**
129         * Returns the simple names of all resources within this class's directory
130         * (excluding the class file itself).
131         * This should work in an ordinary file system as well as a (possibly nested) 
132         * JAR file.
133         * 
134         * @return A sorted array of names (possibly empty)
135         */
136        public String[] getResourceNames() {
137                final String className = clazz.getSimpleName();
138                Path[] paths = getResourcePaths(getResourcePath(""));
139                List<String> nameList = new ArrayList<>(paths.length);
140                for (Path p : paths) {
141                        String name = p.getFileName().toString();
142                        // exclude .java and .class files of THIS class
143                        String nameOnly = FileUtils.stripFileExtension(name);
144                        if (!nameOnly.equals(className)) {
145                                nameList.add(name);
146                        }
147                }
148                String[] sa = nameList.toArray(new String[0]);
149                Arrays.sort(sa);
150                return sa;
151        }
152        
153        // ----------------------------------------------------------------------
154        
155        /**
156         * Finds the URI for a resource relative to (in the directory/package of) this class.
157         * The resource may be located in the file system or inside a JAR file.
158         * 
159         * @param resourceName The resource's simple name (including file extension)
160         * @return The URI or {@code null} if the resource was not found
161         */
162        private URI getURI(String resourceName) {
163                URI uri = null;
164                if (isInsideJAR()) {
165                        String classPath = clazz.getProtectionDomain().getCodeSource().getLocation().getFile();
166                        //String packagePath = clazz.getPackage().getName().replace('.', File.separatorChar);
167                        String packagePath = clazz.getPackage().getName().replace('.', '/');
168                        String compPath = "jar:file:" + classPath + "!/" + packagePath + "/" + resourceName;
169                        try {
170                                uri = new URI(compPath);
171                        } catch (URISyntaxException e) {
172                                // throw new RuntimeException("getResourceURI: " + e.toString());
173                        }       
174                }
175                else {  // regular file path
176                        try {
177                                URL url = clazz.getResource(resourceName);
178                                if (url != null) {
179                                        uri = url.toURI();
180                                }
181                        } catch (URISyntaxException e) {
182                                //do nothing, just return null
183                        }
184                }
185                return uri;
186        }
187        
188        /**
189         * Converts an URI to a Path for locations that are either
190         * in the file system or inside a JAR file.
191         * 
192         * @param uri The specified location (URI)
193         * @return The associated path
194         */
195        private static Path uriToPath(URI uri) {
196                Path path = null;
197                String scheme = uri.getScheme();
198                switch (scheme) {
199                case "jar":     {       // resource inside JAR file
200                        FileSystem fs = null;
201                        try { // check if this FileSystem already exists 
202                                fs = FileSystems.getFileSystem(uri);
203                        } catch (FileSystemNotFoundException e) {
204                                // that's OK to happen, the file system is not created automatically
205                        }
206                        
207                        if (fs == null) {       // must not create the file system twice
208                                try {
209                                        fs = FileSystems.newFileSystem(uri, Collections.<String, Object>emptyMap());
210                                } catch (IOException e) {
211                                        throw new RuntimeException("uriToPath: " + e.toString());
212                                }
213                        }
214                        
215                        String ssp = uri.getSchemeSpecificPart();
216                        int startIdx = ssp.lastIndexOf('!');
217                        String inJarPath = ssp.substring(startIdx + 1);  // in-Jar path (after the last '!')
218                        path = fs.getPath(inJarPath);
219                        break;
220                }
221                case "file": {  // resource in ordinary file system
222                        path = Paths.get(uri);
223                        break;
224                }
225                default:
226                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("Cannot handle this URI type: " + scheme);
227                }
228                return path;
229        }
230        
231        /**
232         * Returns the paths to all files in a directory specified
233         * by a path. This should work in an ordinary file system
234         * as well as a (possibly nested) JAR file.
235         * 
236         * @param path The path to a directory (may be contained in a JAR file) 
237         * @return An array of paths or {@code null} if the specified path 
238         * is not a directory
239         */
240        private static Path[] getResourcePaths(Path path) {
241                // with help from http://stackoverflow.com/questions/1429172/how-do-i-list-the-files-inside-a-jar-file, #10
242                if (!Files.isDirectory(path)) {
243                        throw new IllegalArgumentException("path is not a directory: " + path.toString());
244                }
245                
246                List<Path> pathList = new ArrayList<Path>();
247                Stream<Path> walk = null;
248                try {
249                        walk = Files.walk(path, 1);
250                } catch (IOException e) {
251                        e.printStackTrace();
252                }
253
254                for (Iterator<Path> it = walk.iterator(); it.hasNext();){
255                        Path p = it.next();
256                        if (Files.isRegularFile(p) && Files.isReadable(p)) {
257                                pathList.add(p);
258                        }
259                }
260                walk.close();
261                return pathList.toArray(new Path[0]);
262        }
263        
264}
